messages: ae77e2fa7e98c6bf3f5e2cf455f090aa (02:00): bobhope: I'm a fan of defining my arrays before I cann the function, passing them into the function, and just using the function to init them.
ae77e2fa7e98c6bf3f5e2cf455f090aa (02:00): Wow.  I can manage the weirdest typos.
82f0492fb94c5d7aad27f6ce1bb7595f (02:01): Baughn: do I want to staticly link my libraries before valgrinding?
e2d13e5329d8979a94cac3725f1bbe55 (02:01): is there a simplier way to do
70c6ff03cbb88a833a8bdb91fec2fe46 (02:01): magari: Yes. Compiling /and/ linking, please. No -s, preferably no -O.
f5709af03c9b28dc263042e62d15b506 (02:01): DDustinWork: what are you trying to do?
5dcf63aff1646cd76108fa0f4e06237a (02:02): CSWookie: I'm not, it gives me the creeps
e2d13e5329d8979a94cac3725f1bbe55 (02:02): maw: check if the begining part of the string matches some pattern, in this case -h
e2d13e5329d8979a94cac3725f1bbe55 (02:02): beck: hm, yeah that could work
d68c4615161218922ef991850ceb8d36 (02:02): well thats what i use
70c6ff03cbb88a833a8bdb91fec2fe46 (02:02): DDustinWork: If you're parsing command-line arguments, getopt is way nicer. It'll treat -rf the same as -r -f, which you probably want.
e2d13e5329d8979a94cac3725f1bbe55 (02:03): does getopt come with mingw?

ae77e2fa7e98c6bf3f5e2cf455f090aa (02:03): bobhope: Well, your code I suppose.  I try to use automatic variables whenever possible, and I'm willing to bend a little to do it.  Forgetting ot free is super easy.
ae77e2fa7e98c6bf3f5e2cf455f090aa (02:04): bobhope: Then you should agree with me about passing pointers downstack, rather than up.
e2d13e5329d8979a94cac3725f1bbe55 (02:04): BUGS       This manpage is confusing.
ae77e2fa7e98c6bf3f5e2cf455f090aa (02:05): DDustinWork: What man is that?
70c6ff03cbb88a833a8bdb91fec2fe46 (02:05): DDustinWork: I much prefer the POSIX manpages. They aren't.
e2d13e5329d8979a94cac3725f1bbe55 (02:05): eh, ill just stick with strstr
70c6ff03cbb88a833a8bdb91fec2fe46 (02:05): Of course, POSIX uses "shall be" a lot, and "is" very rarely. Fortunately it's usually right.
ae77e2fa7e98c6bf3f5e2cf455f090aa (02:06): Baughn: This manpage SHALL BE confusing?
e2d13e5329d8979a94cac3725f1bbe55 (02:06): yeah that 'thous shalt' stuff is just weird
70c6ff03cbb88a833a8bdb91fec2fe46 (02:06): CSWookie: Nah. It says "This manpage MAY be confusing".
8a3d27caee5b07d7a923c1b25f7c52eb (02:11): getopt seems to be rather bad
70c6ff03cbb88a833a8bdb91fec2fe46 (02:11): Oh, it's a mess. But it's still useful.
8a3d27caee5b07d7a923c1b25f7c52eb (02:12): I've used it a few times, but now I'm thinking I really don't need it, and that I should be better off without it.
70c6ff03cbb88a833a8bdb91fec2fe46 (02:13): You'd be better off writing a new one, rather - but for some reason I haven't.
72d59c6192480e742d78a38be72806d1 (02:17): and there is also suboptions which i haven't tried
5dcf63aff1646cd76108fa0f4e06237a (02:21): Erm, used malloc instead but i still have a prob
5dcf63aff1646cd76108fa0f4e06237a (02:22): still get the error: incompatible types in assignment
161747ec4dc9f55f1760195593742232 (02:23): you sure you're using a C compiler? o_O
ab83e72bc5b788b2440732d3091d6a9d (02:25): i do not like all of those warnings
ab83e72bc5b788b2440732d3091d6a9d (02:25): some of those things are perfectly ok to do
70c6ff03cbb88a833a8bdb91fec2fe46 (02:25): It will at least make people think
161747ec4dc9f55f1760195593742232 (02:25): or want to shoot themselves in the head
5dcf63aff1646cd76108fa0f4e06237a (02:28): all these errors... does this mean I'm a bad bad programmer? *weep*
5c605d51c4e83fb5351d72b8f40d242b (02:31): I can post the whole thing here: bob.c:72: error: incompatible types in assignment
70c6ff03cbb88a833a8bdb91fec2fe46 (02:31): LiNiX: Paste line 72 while you're at it.
0f870ace0a4b9665e30aafebc5bc149c (02:31): maybe a silly question, but if I have a double literal... how do I get this as a block of bytes ?
